Maryland Port Administration





Workers for heavy industry, 1925



.

The next watershed in the history of
the port came in 1887 with the founding of
the Maryland Steel Co. and the beginning
of the present Sparrows Point steel works.
Financed by sources associated with the
Pennsylvania Railroad, it relied on a simple
equation: importation of iron ore from
Cuba (later from elsewhere), plus direct
rail transportation of coal and limestone
from Pennsylvania, plus a convenient labor
supply in nearby Baltimore, equals efficiency
and profits. From the first, the Sparrows
Point plant was intended to produce a full

Canning of oysters and vegetables was a prime waterfront industry in Baltimore, late 19th and early 20th centuries. An oyster canning house, 1904.



range of steel products and build ships.
Today the Bethlehem Steel Corp. is the
largest single private employer in the
Baltimore region.

The Sparrows Point plant was the har-
binger of a new pattern of port development,
the siting of large industrial plants along
the reaches of the Patapsco River itself.
The first World War saw the building of an
Army Ordinance Depot and Coast Guard
Yard along the upper Curtis Creek, and
large chemical plants on Curtis Bay.
Further east at Fairfield a new shipbuilding
yard was established to build merchant
ships and barges, and Hawkins Point was
used for ammunition storage. In the 1920s
the Maryland Shipbuilding and Dry Dock
Co. was located at Fairfield, and World
War Il saw a vast expansion of the old Fair-
field yard to produce Liberty and Victory
ships and LSTs. Large copper smelting
plants and oil and sugar refineries filled
out the pattegn of industrialization.

After World War 1l the port prospered
for a time from the export of grain and
coal under the United Nations Relief and
Rehabilitation Program in behalf of the
war devastated nations, and by continued
growth of the Sparrows Point steel plant.
The Fairfield building yard became a ship-
breaking yard and salvage operation. But
the pattern was now clear: Baltimore had
become a bulk cargo port serving large
